children.value: In this article, I will talk about writing test for react component, connected component, hoc, react hooks, redux saga function (generator function), and function with promise. In the end, I will also talk about an important technique: how to mock functions.
Examples are available in this git repo:
We will begin with tests for react component with
. If you have already worked with Enzyme, you should know that there are
for rendering the component. Mount is for rendering the full DOM while shallow will not render the sub component unless you
Imagine that we have a component with the name of "Com" with another component "SubCom" inside. Here is an example of test:
"should have classes with name of container and subContainer"
// need to find the SubComponent in shallow rendering
"func should be executed if we click on subComponent"
2. Test with connected component and HOC (Higher Order Component)
in react-redux is a higher order component. I will give two examples about how to test a connected component, and how to test another higher order component like
"Should be able to test connected component"
// in need of a Provider for connected component
"should be able to test redux form"
, so test with saga function is to play with the
in generator function. Every 'yield' should correspond to an execution with 'next()'.
4. Test with function who returns promise
, but it is also possible to test the promise by mocking the execution of promise with 'then'.
"should return ok if input is true with .resolves"
"should return ok if input is true with .then"
// remember to return the promise in the end
"should return error if input is false with .rejects"
"should return error if input is false with .then"
In order to test hooks, I use

. React testing library is competitor of Enzyme for react integration test. The idea behind this library is to test the DOM by simulating the real user interface. It is like "mount" in Enzyme. (Update 2019/08/27: Enzyme now also supports hooks.)
We can test graphql queries by providing a
for mocked query responses. An example will be shown in the next part 'Test custom hooks'.
If the query is made by the hook
and if it is used only once in the component, it is not a bad way to mock
to return the expected result. (For more information:
How to mock dependencies in jest: the pitfalls, the tricks and the best practices
A custom Hook is a JavaScript function whose name starts with use and that may call other Hooks.
Component is for the UI, then the custom hook is for your component logic. It can be how we get and format data, and it can be also how to handle the callbacks.

Without a library, it is not easy to test a custom hook independently because it "lives" in a component.
Luckily the library
Let's take an example of a custom hook which uses two other hooks (useContext and useQuery).
// use graphql hook to get data
// the hook use context and query, in this case we need to create wrapper for test
/* MockedProvider from apollo to mock query responses */
/* Wrap context provider for hook wrapper */
/* the children here is necessary, if not the hook won't be rendered*/

frontmatter.title: Write test for React: component, hoc, hooks, promise, saga, graphql, custom hooks
